description: Made by Professor D. E. Hughes, F.R.S. Presented by the Executors of the late Mrs. Anna C. Hughes. In the course of some experiments with his Induction Balance, Prof. Hughes found that if a circuit was formed by joining up in series a battery, a microphone, and one of the coils of his balance, any interruption of the circuit was accompanied by a disturbance which became audible in a telephone receiver connected to another microphone, even when the two circuits were widely separated and there was no direct connection between them. Prof. Hughes carried out a great many experiments, many of which were witnessed by eminent men of science, but whereas Prof. Hughes was convinced that they were due to some form of conduction between the two circuits, his friends eventually came to the conclusion that they could all be accounted for by the known laws of electro-magnetic induction. It is now certain that in these experiments, Hughes, like Edison in 1875, was dealing with true Hertzian waves such as now used in wireless telegraphy, and that he was unwittingly employing for their detection the coherer method of reception which was first deliberately used for this purpose by Lodge in 1889. The microphone detector exhibited consists of a steel needle hanging in light contact with a small circular hole in a block of carbon, and is one of many forms of microphone which were tried by Prof. Hughes. Others will be found in the telephony section.

description:
Throughout the experimental researches of Prof. Hertz, to which is due the rise of modern wireless telegraphy, the only means of detection was that afforded by the occurrence of a minute visible spark in a closed circuit tuned to resonance with the transmitter.
In repeating the experiments of Hertz, Sir Oliver Lodge also employed a “resonator” which, however, was made to resemble the oscillator in shape and consisted of a straight rod interrupted at the centre by an adjustable spark gap. One of these resonators is here shown, and it will be seen that the wood base on which it is mounted is blackened behind the gap in order to render the spark more easily visible.
Although thousands of times less sensitive than the coherer, which Sir Oliver Lodge and others subsequently employed, it was by means of resonators such as these that Prof. Hertz laid the foundations of modern wireless telegraphy, performing experiments involving reflection, refraction, and polarization of electro-magnetic waves.
Sir Oliver Lodge also employed resonators in conjunction with coherer detection, which he placed in the position of the spark gap. With such apparatus he transmitted signals a distance of some 60 yards in 1894, using as one of his accessory pieces of apparatus a coherer and tapper.

description:
This Hertzian oscillator was used by Sir Oliver Lodge in 1894, when in the course of experiments based on the work of Hertz he transmitted signals over a short distance by means of electric waves.
The oscillator is similar in every way to the type used by Prof. H. Hertz at Karlsruhe in 1886, and is known as a “dumb-bell” oscillator or “dipole.”
The only fundamental change which has taken place in the growth of such oscillators from the small experimental model (used purely for physical research) to the large modern antennæ measuring up to 800 ft. in height, is that it has become customary to replace the lower half of the dipole by an earth connection.
This important modification was made by G. Marconi in 1895.
Sir Oliver Lodge himself came very near to the experimental demonstration of electro-magnetic waves, and was the first to show the fundamental importance of tuning in wireless.

description: The sphere when excited gave sparks at the ends of a diameter to two small knobs and emitted waves 7 in. in length. The radiation was very powerful, but owing to the high rate of damping the oscillator was enclosed in a copper screening device with a variable aperture, in order to prolong the duration of the waves and project them in any desired direction. At his Lecture in 1894, “On the work of Hertz and some of his successors,” Sir Oliver Lodge used this oscillator to transmit signals from the library of the Royal Institution to the lecture table, where they were detected by his spring coherer. He also demonstrated the quasi-optical effects of the waves by refracting and polarizing them, as Hertz had done.

description:
This spark-gap, originally used for experiments on lightning guards, was employed by Sir Oliver Lodge in 1889 as a detector of electro-magnetic waves. It represents the first deliberate application of the coherer principle to wireless reception.
In that year Sir Oliver Lodge accidentally observed that when lightning struck the guard, the opposite sides of the protective air-gap became fused together. This he considered partly due to a cohesive action, resulting in adhesion and amalgamation when a spark occurred between the knobs. An extremely feeble spark was found sufficient to produce the effect provided that the surfaces were only separated by an almost imperceptible film, probably of oxide. The adhesion of the two surfaces was demonstrated by an electric bell and battery in circuit; every time a spark occurred the bell rang, and if it was placed so that its vibrations could reach the cohered surfaces a few strokes sufficed to break the contact and restore the gap to its original condition. Sir Oliver Lodge called this arrangement a "coherer," a name that has since been applied to all modes of detection using either a single specially arranged contact-gap or a multiplicity of loose contacts. Inv. 1924-36, S.M. 2174.

description: Plate 3. Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers. 1898-1902 A number of objects are shown which illustrate the work of the Marconi Company between the years 1898 and 1902. They include oscillation transformers or "jiggers" (A–G), condensers and inductance coils (H–K), and types of detectors used by Senatore Marconi (L–N). The mercury-iron anti-coherer is one of several which were used in Newfoundland when the first transatlantic wireless signals were received there in 1901. (See also No. 17.) In the mercury-iron coherer the original form of which was devised by P. Castelli, a signalman in the Italian Navy, two electrodes, either both of iron or one of iron and one of carbon, are placed in a glass tube, and between the electrodes is a drop of mercury. The Marconi magnetic detector is described at No. 33.

description: This is part of the first piece of rough experimental tuned coupled-circuit transmitting apparatus employed by Senatore Marconi at his station at "The Haven," Poole Harbour, in 1899. It is the foundation of the famous "7777" patent of 1900. The improvements embodied in this patent were as follows:—At the transmitting end the original arrangement, called since then a "plain aerial," was exchanged for one consisting of two coupled circuits. The secondary of the oscillation transformer was connected in series with an adjustable inductance in the aerial circuit, while the primary circuit included a spark gap and condenser. It is this latter portion of the original experimental apparatus which is here shown. It consists of a square wooden frame over which are wound several lengths of thickly insulated copper cable joined in parallel to form a single turn of very low resistance. The condenser and the terminals of the spark gap were connected to the secondary terminals of a 10-in. induction coil (shown at No. 10). The whole oscillation transformer when in use was generally immersed in insulating oil.

description: It was in 1898 that Senatore Marconi first introduced into his receiving arrangements a "jigger," or oscillation transformer. In his previous work he had placed the receiving coherer directly in the aerial circuit, but since the coherer, like most forms of detector, is a potential-operated device, and since there is always an antinode of potential at the earthed end of an aerial system, the arrangement was not an efficient one. Marconi therefore adopted the plan of inserting in the aerial circuit the primary coil of a small air-core transformer, to the secondary terminals of which the coherer was connected, and thus produced the coupled-circuit receiver which is now so familiar. Several of the earliest types of "jigger" are shown under No. 8. The example here shown was standardized in 1900 for use with the first commercial tuned apparatus working on a wave-length of 60 metres (Tune "A"). The instrument was known as Type No. 306, signifying that in the experimental investigations carried out to determine the best types of receiving transformer, the one finally adopted for Tune "A" stood 306th on the experimental list. No. 343 was standardized for Tune "B" (about 300 metres), and No. 268 for "plain aerial" working.

description: This early form of coherer-receiver was made and used by the Marconi Company. It consists of a sensitive metal filings coherer with an electro-magnetic tapper, and forms part of a circuit containing a local battery and a sensitive telegraphic relay. When electro-magnetic waves energise the transformer, or "jigger," contained in the apparatus, the metal particles cohere, causing the resistance of the tube to fall from a high value to a lower one, depending upon the strength of the received signals. A current of the order of one milliampere flows from a single cell, operating the relay, causing current from several other dry cells to operate the tapper and morse inker. The signal is thus recorded, and the tapper decoheres the tube, restoring it to a condition of high resistance.
interpretation: This early form of coherer-receiver was used for wireless telegraphy.

description: These are the original thermionic tubes which were made and used by Prof. Fleming in the experiments which led him from an investigation of the so-called Edison effect in 1883 to the invention in 1904 of the two-electrode thermionic valve. These valves were the precursors of other types, and with them have given rise to highly important developments in wireless telegraphy and telephony. In 1883 Mr. T. A. Edison experimented with a glow lamp having a metal plate sealed into the exhausted bulb and a carbon filament rendered incandescent by a direct electric current. He discovered that if the metal plate was connected to the positive terminal of the filament by an external wire, a feeble electric current flowed through it, whereas hardly any current flowed when the plate was connected to the negative terminal. Mr. Edison himself gave no explanation of this effect. It was assumed in 1889 that there was an emission of negatively electrified carbon atoms from the filament, but in 1899 Sir J. J. Thomson showed that they were particles of negative electricity, now called electrons. These are projected at a high speed from the incandescent filament and attracted to a positively electrified metal plate sealed into the bulb. The effect is now known as Thermionic Emission. In 1889 Prof. Fleming commenced a systematic investigation of the Edison effect, and constructed for this purpose the series of vacuous bulbs lettered A to I. Bulb C was constructed in order to prove that thermionic emission takes place in the case of an incandescent platinum wire as well as in that of an incandescent carbon filament. Bulbs D, E and F were used to test how far from the filament the emitted particles could travel to a positively electrified metal plate, and whether they could travel round an elbow-tube or only in straight lines. It was found that the thermionic current became weaker as the distance between the filament and plate (or "anode") was increased. Bulbs G and H were used to investigate the emission from various parts of the filament, and it was shown to be prevented by enclosing the carbon filament in a glass tube. In bulb I provision was made for the interposition of a mica plate between the anode and filament in order to find out if the transfer of negative electricity was thereby stopped. It was found that this was so. Bulbs J, K, L and M are samples of the two electrode thermionic valves which were the outcome of the foregoing experiments. Electrons are evaporated from an incandescent carbon or tungsten filament and attracted to the anode which is positively charged by means of a battery. The space between the filament and anode thus allows negative electricity to pass in one direction, but not in the opposite, and it can therefore convert the high-frequency alternating current set up in a wireless receiver into a direct current (i.e., rectify it). The sensitivity of the device is about the same as that of a crystal detector but it is completely stable in its action.

description: This lightning protector, which was patented in 1866 by C. and S. A. Varley, is a duplicate of one shown in the telegraphy section. It is repeated here because its action depends upon that coherence of semi-conducting powders which was afterwards utilised in the reception of Hertzian waves. As early as 1838, Munck, of Rosenschild, noticed a diminution of resistance in tubes containing metallic filings or semi-conducting bodies, when traversed by electric currents. He also ascertained that these powders regained their original resistance after having been subjected to some mechanical disturbance. In 1852, the high resistance of uncohered metallic powder was again noticed by S. A. Varley, and four years later he detected a sudden fall in its resistance during a thunderstorm. In 1866, Messrs. C. and S. A. Varley took out a patent for the present lightning arrestor. In the patent specification they observed that powdered conducting matter constitutes a poor conductor under low electro-motive forces, but that its conductivity is remarkably increased when it is subjected to high potentials. The connection between these discoveries, together with those of Prof. Hughes in 1879, and Prof. Calzecchi-Onesti, of Fermo, in 1884, and the later history of the coherer is one of considerable interest.

description: Plate 2. Made by Mr. E. E. Robinson. Presented by Sir Oliver Lodge, F.R.S. 1894 This very early form of coherer was used by Sir Oliver Lodge in a number of his experiments with Hertzian waves. In one such experiment exhibited before the Royal Institution in 1894, he sent and received signals over a distance of some twenty yards using the spherical oscillator shown at No. 4. The coherer consists of a spiral of thin iron wire, mounted on an adjustable spindle, and an aluminium plate. When the lever is moved clockwise the tip of the iron wire presses gently against the aluminium plate, whose end is bent at right angles and passed through into the hollow circular wooden box. The device is similar in principle to Sir Oliver Lodge's spark-gap coherer of 1889. (See No. 5.)

description: Plate 2. Made by Mr. E. E. Robinson. Presented by Sir Oliver Lodge, F.R.S. 1890 In 1890, Prof. E. Branly, of Paris, made the extremely important observation that an electric spark at a distance had the power of suddenly changing the electric conductivity of loose masses of powdered conductors. He showed that a tube of metallic filings loosely packed between metal plugs might be a conductor of very high resistance when the metallic filings were loosely arranged, but that if a discharge from a Leyden jar was made in the vicinity, the conductivity of the metallic powder was suddenly increased. Similar observations had been made previously by other experimenters (see No. 21), but this was the first time that a careful study was made of the phenomenon. In 1894, Sir Oliver Lodge conducted some experiments using the actual tubes shown, which were similar to those of Branly. Each consists of a glass tube filled loosely with coarse filings or borings of iron contained between two metal plugs. Sir Oliver Lodge noticed that the change of resistance of the tube was proportional to the energy of electric radiation from a source of given frequency. He arranged an electro-magnetic vibrating arrangement (shown in one specimen) to produce mechanical agitation, and so destroy the incipient cohesion caused by the electric radiation. A similar arrangement was adopted by Popoff in Russia and Marconi in Italy. One of these tubes, found to have a resistance of 2,500 ohms in the sensitive state. A feeble stimulus reduced it by 400 ohms, while a rather stronger spark reduced it by 500 and 600 ohms. Inv. 1924-37, S.M. 2174.

description: This is an early Marconi coherer and Admiralty pattern tapper arranged to tap the glass coherer tube on the cessation of a signal. The decoherer consists of a relay wound to a resistance of about 1,000 ohms. The relay is made to operate a small electro-magnet having a vibrating armature like an electric bell, this armature carrying a hammer. The electro-magnet is so fixed on an inclined plane that the blow is administered to the sensitive tube upwards from below. Delicate screw adjustments are also provided by means of which the exact strength of the blows, and the rate at which they are given, can be precisely controlled. In the circuit of the sensitive tube are two choking coils, the effect of which is to prevent the oscillations started by the minute sparks at the relay or vibrating hammer contacts, travelling back along the wires and causing coherence in the filings.

description: Used later in 1901 This is the form of coherer used in 1897 by the Allgemeine Elektricitats-Gesellschaft in the Slaby-Arco system of radio-telegraphy. It was used later by the British post office in experiments between Baldoyle and Howth in 1901. The coherer consists of an exhausted glass tube, narrower at its central portion, into which enter two tightly fitting silver plugs. The plugs serve as conductors, to which are soldered two little capsules cemented to the ends of the tube. A fine powder is enclosed between the faces of which are not parallel, one of them being cut on the skew so that the gap left for the powder is V-shaped. The powder only fills about half of this space, and if the coherer is placed in such a manner that the narrower portion of V space is downwards, the powder occupies the greater height in the gap, its pressure is greater, and the sensitiveness of the apparatus is at its maximum. If, on the contrary, the larger portion of the V is turned downwards, the powder takes a lower level, and exercises less pressure, so that the sensitiveness of the coherer is at a minimum. The tube is rested on supports that permit it to rotate; this gives a means of controlling the degree of sensitiveness.

description: This coherer was patented in 1902, and perfected by Sir Oliver Lodge and Dr. Alexander Muirhead, who had always advocated continuous decoherence by means of magnetic tappers then in use, wherein electro-magnetic tappers were brought into operation only on the receipt of signals. A small and perfectly true steel wheel is specially ground to a smooth knife edge and is kept in rotation by the clockwork which drives the siphon recorder used to record the messages received. The edge of the wheel grazes the convex surface of a small column of mercury contained in an ebonite cup, the height of which can be adjusted so that the wheel dips more or less below the surface. A drop of oil is placed on the top of the cup, and a small pad of wash-leather bears upon the edge of the wheel to keep it clean. An adjustable potential divider, supplied by a battery, maintains a potential difference just insufficient to break down the film of oil which the rotation of the wheel draws in between its edge and the mercury. The oscillating potential difference set up by an incoming wave-train breaks down this film, allowing a current to pass at the place of contact and operating the siphon recorder. On the cessation of each wave-train, the oil is drawn in again, decohering the instrument, i.e., restoring it to its normal resistance, which is almost infinite. In reliability and sensitiveness this appliance was superior to any detector known at the time, and signals were received with great reliability and precision in express trains at 60 m.p.h. Inv. 1923-441.

description: Presented by R. P. Howgrave-Graham, Esq. Introduced about 1904 This ingenious and very sensitive coherer was introduced about 1904 by Sir Oliver Lodge and Dr. Alexander Muirhead. description: This is a detector of the self-restoring type, invented by Mr. S. G. Brown, Esq., F.R.S. It is sometimes classed as a coherer and at others as an electrolytic detector. It consists essentially of a pellet of peroxide of lead held between a plate of lead and one of platinum. If an external electromotive force from a single secondary cell is impressed upon it so that the current flows through the peroxide from platinum to lead, a counter electromotive force will be experienced by this current due to the electro-chemical action of the lead-peroxide of lead-platinum couple. Mr. Brown found that the passage of oscillations through this couple increased its counter electro-motive force by stimulating chemical action, and so reducing the current sent through it by the external cell. The couple acts, therefore, as a conductor of which the resistance is increased by electric oscillations. The pellet of peroxide is mounted in a holder in which an adjustable pressure can be applied, and placed in series with a galvanometer and single cell. When oscillations occur the deflection of the galvanometer decreases, but increases again when they cease.

description: The action of this detector is to some extent based on the results of experiments by Prof. Sir E. Rutherford and others. It was patented by Senatore Marconi in 1902, and was largely used in ship receiving sets on account of its reliability. An endless band, consisting of a number of strands of insulated iron wire, passes over two pulleys which are made to rotate slowly by clockwork. Near to a part of the band two horseshoe magnets are fixed with similar poles adjacent, and at this point, where a large number of lines of force pass into the band, the latter passes through a tube surrounded by two coils. The inner coil is connected with the aerial and earth wires, and the outer coil with the telephone receiver. This arrangement of magnets and coils is duplicated at another point of the band so that two telephones may be used or the coils may be connected in series, which often increases the strength of the signals. As the band travels slowly through the coils, the lines of force are drawn out in the direction of its motion owing to the retentivity of the iron, but when oscillatory currents arrive from the aerial circuit these lines are freed and a rapid change takes place in the magnetic field. This causes a current to flow through both coil and telephone circuit and gives a signal. (See also No. 196.) Inv.

description: The use of crystal detectors in receiving circuits renders it possible to “detect” the high-frequency currents set up in the receiving aerial, by completely rectifying the alternating current into a current whose mean value is no longer zero, and then using a polarised electro-magnetic indicator (a telephone). This is due to the fact that with certain minerals, usually crystalline, the resistance to the flow of electricity across the contact between a piece of metal, and a piece of the mineral, or between two pieces of different minerals, depends largely on the value of the current, even when the current is extremely small, and does not obey Ohm's law. Thus the P.D. current characteristic has a pronounced curvature, and consequently if an alternating E.M.F., whose mean value is zero, is applied to the crystal the mean value of the resulting current is not zero. This current is spoken of as the “rectified current.” The specimen shown is a silicon crystal, the contact being made between a crystal of silicon and steel. It is now mounted in a locket, but it was formerly used in the wireless installation of the cargo vessel S.S. “Nonsuch.” This was the first British cargo vessel to carry a wireless installation, and on September 16th, 1910, when off the coast of Morocco, she received messages from the North Foreland Station, a distance of 940 nautical miles. Such a range of reception was at this time very unusual, and it was, of course, due to a fortunate conjunction of circumstances in which the crystal itself played only a secondary, though necessary, part. (See also No. 41.) Inv. 1916-73.

description: This detector, for which a patent was applied for by Dr. Lee de Forest in 1901, depends for its action on the increase of resistance in an electrollizable mixture caused by the passage of an oscillatory current. The detector itself consists of a tube containing two small metal electrode plugs, between the ends of which is a space of about 1/200 in. In this space is placed an electrollizable mixture of glycerine or vaseline mixed with water or alcohol, and a small quantity of litharge and metallic filings. These metallic filings act as secondary electrodes. If a small E.M.F. is applied to the electrodes of this tube through a resistance of about 25,000 ohms, and the two electrodes are connected to aerial and earth respectively, then theory supposes that on the arrival of a signal, oscillatory currents will pass through the cell, where they break up the chains of metallic particles. This interrupts the current passing through the telephones, and gives rise to a click. A rapid succession of oscillatory sparks is heard as a short continuous sound in the telephone receivers.

object_name: APPARATUS TO ILLUSTRATE THE PRINCIPLES OF SPARK TELEGRAPHY
description: The apparatus here shown represents a transmitting and a receiving group constructed for demonstration purposes in the early days of wireless telegraphy. The transmitter comprises a small induction coil, to the secondary terminals of which two adjustable metal spheres are connected: a Morse key is connected in the primary circuit. The primary condenser consists of alternate sheets of tinfoil and paper, and is joined across the interrupter contacts, its functions being to reduce the break spark, and to demagnetise the core quickly. The intermittent high voltages generated in the secondary coil produce charges on the secondary condenser, setting up a state of electric strain across the gap. When the gap is set to such a width that the maximum charge on the condenser reaches a value sufficient to break down the insulation of the air, a current will flow across the gap. After a small fraction of time the discharge equalises the potentials, causing the electric strain to be removed; ultimately the condenser again charges up, and discharges across the gap, but in the opposite direction. By this means, electro-magnetic waves are generated, and radiated through the aether, the waves being heavily damped, owing to the losses in the circuit. The receiver consists of two long strips of copper foil arranged in the same line, but separated by a coherer. This consists of a narrow glass tube, exhausted of air, having two plugs of silver attached to platinum wires. Between these plugs is a space partly filled with a metallic powder, composed of 95 per cent. nickel and 5 per cent. silver. In its normal state this presents a high resistance to the passage of an electric current. When electric oscillations are set up in the coherer circuit, the resistance falls very considerably owing to an apparent cohesion of the filings, and a current can pass of sufficient strength to operate a relay. The resistance remains at its low value until the tube is tapped and decohered. The tapper consists of an electro-magnet having vibrating armature arranged in circuit with the coherer and battery. Immediately the coherer becomes a conductor the armature is pulled down, thereby completing another circuit containing battery and electric bell, the clapper of which communicates vibration to the metallic powder. The moment the electro-magnetic radiation ceases, the final blow of the clapper renders the coherer a non-conductor, thus breaking the bell circuit.

description: This type of receiver, patented in 1907 by Mr. C. S. Franklin and the makers, was much used on Marconi ship outfits in conjunction with the magnetic detector. The detector, being of low resistance, works on current rather than voltage effects, and hence in this receiver, capacity effects predominate and inductance effects are small. The receiver has three circuits, aerial, intermediate, and detector, each of which must be tuned, and the tuning switches are so connected together that the three circuits may be roughly tuned simultaneously. Finer adjustments are then made by means of the three variable condensers in the three circuits. These condensers are seen on the top of the case. The degree of coupling may be altered by moving the axis of the coils of the intermediate circuit relatively to the aerial and detector circuit coils. This is effected by rotating a handle on the side of the case. The aerial loading inductance is adjusted by means of a multiple contact switch on the left front of the case. A two-way throw-over switch is mounted on the top of the case; in the “stand-by” position it connects the detector directly into the aerial circuit, and when signals are received it is thrown over to the “tune” position so that the detector circuit is coupled to the intermediate circuit and accurate tuning can take place. The instrument is designed to tune to all wave lengths from 300 ft. to 8,000 ft.

description: Designed for the Army in 1914 This tuner was designed for the Army in 1914 by Major H. P. T. Lefroy, R.E. It comprises the usual aerial and closed circuits, across either of which the detector and telephones can be connected by means of a switch. The design of the inductances should be noted. The range of wave lengths covered is from 500 to 1,500 metres.

description: Made by Army Signals Experimental Establishment. Lent by The War Office. During the War (1914–1918). This tuner, which was designed during the War (1914–1918), is suitable for the reception of wave lengths ranging from 2,500 to 10,500 metres. With the change-over switch at the “stand by” position, the detector is connected direct in the aerial circuit for quick searching. description:
Plate 6. Made by Gesellschaft F. Drahtlose Telegraphie. Lent by The Institution of Electrical Engineers. This receiver, known as type E.8I, was taken from the German warship “Baden,” which was interned at Scapa Flow in February, 1919. Crystal reception is used, and all alterations of circuit and wave-length are effected by means of barrel switches and variable condensers. No metal is used in or near any coils, wooden or bone screws being employed, probably in order to cut down eddy current losses. Most of the coupling rods, cranks, etc., are of insulating material, all joints being pinned. The set, which is now incomplete, is in a box measuring 21 in. by 21 in. by 26 3/4 in., on the top of which was a small motor mounted on felt and worked off 220 volts. This motor was started and stopped by the first motor direction, clockwise or anti-clockwise, of the switch marked “ Prüfschalter ” (test-switch). This drove a small toothed wheel, the teeth bearing on a spring contact and cut and spaced so that the word “ Kiel ” was spelt out in morse. A vibratory contact was also incorporated in this circuit, which was intended to facilitate adjustment of the crystals.
Five of these were detachably fitted and chosen at will by a switch (Detektor Wähler) as well as one “ Tonprüf Detektor ” for use when listening-in.
On the right hand side of the box, at the top, was mounted the “ Syncron-Summer,” an instrument for cutting out interference from a local generator.
On the front is a switch marked “ Schaltungswähler ” (circuit-choosing switch). This has six stops marked :—
(1) Prim. (White Stud).
(2) Prim. (Yellow).
(3) Sek. (Red.)
(4) Sek. (White.)
(5) Leibenröhe (Valve circuit—Red.)
(6) Leibenröhe (White.)
The resulting change of circuit effected is shown on the diagram.
The remaining switches control the capacity, inductance and coupling valves in these circuits.
The valve circuit employed was probably a two-valve high frequency amplifier.

collection: RIGHI PATTERN SHORT WAVE OIL-IMMERSED OSCILLATOR
object_name: RIGHI PATTERN SHORT WAVE OIL-IMMERSED OSCILLATOR
description:
This type of oscillator was invented by Prof. Righi, of Bologna, about 1896, and was used by Senatore Marconi during his early experiments, until superseded by the type of multiple oscillator shown at No. 7. It was also used for the generation of short Hertzian waves, such as are used for demonstrating quasi-optical phenomena.
The immersion of the sparking surfaces in oil tends to increase the incon-veniently small energy of emission which is generally obtained with oscillators of such small capacity, as a high potential difference is reached before the oil breaks down.
The gap resistance is reasonably low immediately after the disruption of the spark, whereas between surfaces far enough apart in air to make the breakdown-strength equal to that of the short oil gap, the ohmic resistance of the spark would be so high that oscillations would be feeble or non-existent. Such oscillators are troublesome as high-power radiators because the oil decomposes, and if the succession of sparks is rapid the oil has not time to close in and fill the gap when a spark has taken place. In such a case only the first of a stream of sparks is oscillatory, and after its passage the oil is worse than useless.

description:
This early form of spark gap consists of two cylindrical steel rods having flat ends, between which the spark is formed. The rods are urged apart by springs, and by compressing the springs the gap can be adjusted.
In all types of gap the passage of the spark ionises the air and makes it temporarily conducting. The gap therefore functions as an automatic switch.
Stationary spark gaps of this kind arc not constant in action. There is a tendency toward the formation of an arc across the ionised gap, wasting power and delaying the recovery of the insulating properties of the gap. Moreover, the interval between successive sparks is apt to be very uneven, as the spark takes place between a succession of pairs of points.

description: This is an early form of rotary spark gap, designed by Mr. J. G. Balsillie, about 1910. The main advantage of such gaps is that any tendency towards arcing is checked by the rotation of the electrodes, which wear out any incipient arc. In the present example this effect is heightened by the peculiar shape of the rotating electrodes, which produce a large air pressure between the surfaces when they are in close proximity. The direction of rotation is, of course, such that the convex surface of a moving electrode is the first to reach the fixed electrode. (See also No. 57.)

description: This instrument is the original model, constructed in 1914, of the high-tension generators working upon the “Buffer Transformer” principle, which were extensively employed during the war in spark transmitting sets (Wilson 130-watt transmitters and 54a transmitters), and later in the Mercantile Marine for ships main and emergency spark transmitters, also in X-ray and electro-medical diathermy apparatus. The instrument takes 5 amperes at 100 volts D.C., and is designed to charge a .01 mfd. condenser to a sparking voltage of 11,000 at a spark frequency of about 600 per second. The instrument consists of a motor-driven interrupter and two transformers, (a) the high-tension transformer, the secondary of which is connected to the spark gap, .01 mfd. condenser, etc., (b) the “buffer transformer,” the secondary of which is connected to a .4 mfd. condenser. The primary windings of the transformers are connected in series with the interrupter. The interrupter consists of a disc of insulating material, mounted on the shaft of the motor, with nine equally spaced copper segments embedded in its outer surface. The copper segments serve to make and break contact with two copper brushes rubbing on the periphery of the disc. When the interrupter is rotated at the correct speed, 4,000 r.p.m., and the signalling key in the supply circuit is closed, the E.M.F.s induced at “make” in the secondary of the “buffer transformer,” set that circuit into a state of continuous oscillation. The interrupter is adjusted so that it opens and closes the primary circuit at moments when the “buffer” secondary current is passing through zero values, so that one half oscillation occurs during “make” and the other half oscillation during “break.” The coupling between these two circuits during “make” causes that half-wave to be higher in amplitude and shorter in duration than the free half-wave during “break.” The oscillation of energy in the “buffer” secondary circuit induces E.M.Fs. in the primary assisting the supply circuit at the moment of closing the circuit and opposing it at the instant of “break.” The primary current, therefore, rises sharply to a maximum and then falls to zero again in time with the secondary oscillation. The interruption of the primary circuit, therefore, takes place when the supply current is at zero value, and there is then little tendency to spark. The effect of the high-tension transformer sets up a high E.M.F. in its secondary at each “make,” which is communicated to the condenser and spark gap connected to the high-tension circuit circuit occurs while the primary is closed and not when it is opened, as in the case in the ordinary Ruhmkorff induction coil.

description: This instrument consists of a vibrating converter with transformer and valve rectifier, and is designed to provide a steady H.T. supply for the transmitters of military wireless field sets. The instrument takes 5-6 amps. at 20 volts and supplies about 50 milliamps. at 1,000 volts. The converter consists essentially of an induction coil having two primary windings wound in opposite directions, and one secondary winding. The two primary windings have one common end, which is connected with the negative pole of the direct-current supply, the other two ends being connected with two contact screws on spring arms between which vibrates a polarised armature carrying a contact. This armature is connected with the positive supply, and by making contact alternately with each primary winding, an alternating E.M.F. is generated in the secondary winding. The converter is designed to give 100 volts at 350 cycles per second, and this E.M.F. is applied to the primary of a transformer and stepped up to about 3,200 volts. The ends of the secondary winding of the transformer are connected with the anodes of two U.3 rectifying valves (not shown) which become alternately about 1,500 volts positive and 1,600 volts negative with respect to a tapping in the middle of the winding. The tapping is connected with the valve filaments through a 1 mfd. condenser, the plates of which are connected with the H.T. positive and negative terminals, and are thus always charged in the same direction by pulses of current. Discharging at the same time through the valves of the transmitter the plates assume, therefore, a potential such that the quantity of electricity flowing in from the transformer is approximately equal to the quantity flowing in from the transmitter. This potential is about 1,000 volts and the "ripple" or amplitude of the alternating component of H.T. voltage is 2 to 3 per cent.

description: Marconi's Wireless Telegraph Company Next in importance after the invention of the original two-electrode valve by Dr. J. A. Fleming in 1904, comes the introduction of a third electrode into the evacuated bulb. This notable step was taken by Dr. Lee de Forest, of the United States, who evolved his three-electrode “Audion” tube in 1907, but did not describe it publicly until 1913; this tube, and the subsequent Lieben-Reisz Gas relay (No. 75) have led up to important achievements in many branches of physics and engineering, particularly in electrical communication. De Forest had been working on the simple rectifying diode of Fleming, which he re-named the “Audion”; but he afterwards transferred this appellation to the three-electrode tube which is his special contribution to the subject. The third electrode consists of a metal strip of wire bent into the form of a grid, and situated between the filament and the anode. It serves as a control element whereby the current between them is influenced. The revolutionary possibilities of the instrument are bound up in the almost complete absence of inertia effects, and in the dependence of the anode current on the potential existing at any time between the grid and the filament. By making appropriate use of these properties the valve may be used as a detector of high frequency currents, as was the original Fleming valve, or as a medium for the amplification of high or low frequency currents, or as a means of generating undamped oscillations. Photographs of two instruments embodying these latter functions, designed by De Forest in 1914, are exhibited. Owing to an imperfect understanding of the rationale of the triode and to a lack of technical resources existing at the time, the Audion valve was not very highly evacuated, and belongs to a class now known as "gas valves." It remained for Dr. I. Langmuir to produce in the "Pliotron" valve the first tube to function entirely by virtue of electrons emitted from the filament. The "Pliotron" is shown at No. 76.

Fleming in 1904, comes the introduction of a third electrode into the evacuated bulb.', 'This notable step was taken by Dr. Lee de Forest, of the United States, who evolved his three-electrode “Audion” tube in 1907, but did not describe it publicly until 1913; this tube, and the subsequent Lieben-Reisz Gas relay (No. 75) have led up to important achievements in many branches of physics and engineering, particularly in electrical communication.', 'The third electrode consists of a metal strip of wire bent into the form of a grid, and situated between the filament and the anode.', 'It serves as a control element whereby the current between them is influenced.', 'The revolutionary possibilities of the instrument are bound up in the almost complete absence of inertia effects, and in the dependence of the anode current on the potential existing at any time between the grid and the filament.', 'By making appropriate use of these properties the valve may be used as a detector of high frequency currents, as was the original Fleming valve, or as a medium for the amplification of high or low frequency currents, or as a means of generating undamped oscillations.', 'Owing to an imperfect understanding of the rationale of the triode and to a lack of technical resources existing at the time, the Audion valve was not very highly evacuated, and belongs to a class now known as "gas valves."', 'It remained for Dr. I. description: Plate 8 (b). Lent by The Right Hon. Sir Henry Norman, Bart. At about the same time that L. de Forest was investigating his three-electrode valve, Messrs. Lieben and Reisz were experimenting in Vienna with a similar appliance. They named this a "Gas Relay," and in its final form it was fully described in November, 1913. Like the Audion, it could be used as a generator of electrical oscillations, but it was intended to be used mainly as an amplifier of speech currents, and it was the first triode to be definitely so employed. The appearance of this tube aroused fresh interest in the whole subject, and the Lieben-Reisz Relay shares with the Audion and the Fleming valve the distinction of having brought about a revolution in methods of electrical communication. The tube differs from the Audion in having an oxide-coated filament, a type which has since been widely used in "dull-emitter" valves. The principle is due to Wehnelt, who, in 1904, discovered that strongly heated oxides, particularly those of calcium and barium, emit electrons at very low voltages. The cathode in this case is a platinum strip 1 metre in length and 0.02 mm. in width, wound in a zigzag form on a glass support, and is coated in the manner described above. The grid is a circular aluminium plate perforated with holes about 3.5 mm. in diameter, while the anode is a short spiral of 2 mm. aluminium wire, placed at the apex of the tube. The cathode is brought to a bright red heat at a temperature of about 1,000 deg. C. by a battery of 30 volts; the necessary anode voltage being 220. In the early experiments it was found difficult to obtain a uniform discharge owing to variation of the gas pressure inside the tube. It was therefore decided to replace the gas discharge with a vapour discharge by introducing mercury vapour inside the tube, constancy of pressure being obtained by means of a small quantity of mercury amalgam placed in the side tube. For speech frequency a magnification constant of 33 was obtained with this relay, and the inventors described a cascade connection similar to those which are now common, by means of which an amplification of 20,000 times was obtained from four tubes. As early as 1913 Dr. A. Meissner, of the Telefunken Company, made experiments with the Lieben-Reisz tube as a generator of continuous oscillations for wireless communication. He coupled the input and output circuits, so producing the famous "Feed-back" or retroactive circuit, and actually succeeded in transmitting speech over a distance of 36 km. by means of a radio-telephone set constructed on this principle.

description: This is a thermionic tube of much historical importance. In all the valves which preceded the pliotron a relatively large amount of residual gas was present in the bulb. This had a very considerable influence in supplying positive ions within it, which tended to neutralise the space charge effect of the electron currents between cathode and anode, and enabled comparatively large currents to be passed at low potentials. But the presence of such an amount of gas as is indicated by a pressure of 1/10,000 mm. of mercury, led to great instability, so that the results obtained with these gas tubes were often most uncertain. Until 1915, however, it had been concluded that the presence of some gas was necessary in a valve. In that year Dr. Irving Langmuir, of the General Electric Company of America, as the result of research based on the earlier work of Dr. J. A> Fleming, Sir J. J. Thomson and Prof. O. W. Richardson, produced the first commercial tubes in which the action was demonstrably due to pure electron discharge from the filament, and not to the presence of minute traces of gas. One of these tubes, a diode, he named a "Kenetron." The other, an example of which is here shown, was called a "Pliotron." In this tube, which is intended for amplification of radio signals, the filament is of tungsten and the grid and anode are of nickel wire. The grid is wound with very fine wire supported on a glass framework, and the characteristic curve is such that the anode-grid slope conductance is about 0.275 ma. per grid volt. The general form of the curve is given by :- ia = A (Va + m Vg).312 where ia is the anode current, Va is the anode voltage, Vg the grid voltage and m a constant depending on the relative shapes and positions of the electrodes. By means of an original mercury condensation pump Dr. Langmuir succeeded in exhausting these tubes down to a pressure o fthe order of 1/100,000 mm. of mercury, at which pressure the characteristics of the valve are perfectly smooth and regular. It is for this reason that practically all modern valves are of the hard type. Inv. 1924-200. S.M. 2154.

description: Produced by Mr. J. H. Round, of the Marconi Company, in 1913. The cylindrical anode and grid construction, now so common, should be compared with the flat plates of the audion valve. Since the performance of the tube depends to a great extent on the degree of vacuum maintained, a means of varying this is provided. It consists of a small pouch blown in the glass and sealed inside the bulb, in which a quantity of asbestos is placed. On warming the asbestos a certain amount of the gas occluded by it is liberated, and in this way the progressive hardening which occurs under certain conditions when the tube is in use can be corrected. The transmitting tube contains three separate filaments which can be used in turn until all three have been burnt out. Successful radio-telephony was carried out by Mr. J. H. Round in June, 1914, with a continuous-wave transmitter containing a tube of this type. The filaments are of the Wehnelt oxide-coated type.

This is one of the largest glass triodes that it has been found practicable to construct, owing to the tendency of the glass envelope to crack at the high temperatures developed. The anode is of nickel, the supply voltage being 2,000 and upwards. The helical grid of molybdenum is supported on three rods of the same material. The filament consumes 5·5 amps. at 18 volts, and the re-entrant construction of the tube makes it possible to shorten the electron path from grid to anode. The triode can be worked without becoming unduly hot with a steady load of 1,500 watts, derived from grid and plate circuits. tube makes it possible to renew the filament and thus indefinitely prolong the life of the triode. This construction has also the effect of providing a long leakage path from grid to anode. The triode is capable of dissipating about 500 watts of electrical energy without becoming overheated, the output of high-frequency energy being 500 to 1,500 watts, depending on the efficiency of the circuit.

description: This type of tube, used for wireless transmission, has a bulb of pure silica. The high melting point of this material and its low coefficient of expansion enable it to be used without fear of collapse or fracture, although within 1 cm. of the sheet molybdenum anode, the working temperature of which is about 1,500 degs. absolute. The grid is constructed of helically wound tungsten wire supported on molybdenum rods. The filament is also of tungsten wire, kept taut by a helical spring of molybdenum. The triode is capable of dissipating 1 kw. at its anode and will deliver up to 3 kw. of high-frequency energy to the transmitting antenna. The anode supply voltage is 4,000 and upwards; the filament consumes 10 amps. at 14 volts.

description: Presented by The Radio Research Board. This consists of a short length of iron wire enclosed in hydrogen in a glass tube. When connected in series with the filament circuit of a thermionic valve it tends to keep the filament current steady. This is due to the fact that the resistance of iron wire increases as its temperature increases.

description: This relay, which combines remarkable sensitivity with unusual robustness, was invented by Capt. L. B. Turner in 1918. Its action depends upon the sudden rise of mean anode current in a triode under certain conditions when passing from the non-oscillating to the oscillating state. In its later developments it has enabled considerable progress to be made in the recording of high-speed wireless signals. Valve relays can be constructed for signals of either high or low frequency. The present example is for wireless signals of wave-lengths between 1,400 and 3,000 metres. A circuit of the type shown in the accompanying diagram is so adjusted that the arrival of a signal raises momentarily the grid potential of the triode sufficiently to start oscillation, and the resultant rise of anode current is used to trip an ordinary electro-magnetic relay. The grid potential is finely adjustable on the potentiometer P, and when it is set, a small amount called the “margin,” below the critical value called the “threshold,” any signal applied to the circuit producing in it a momentary E.M.F. of the right sense and exceeding the margin in amplitude, sets the system into oscillation. The accompanying rise of current in the coils of the relay pulls over the tongue T, short-circuiting the reaction coil and thereby quenching the oscillation, which is thereupon reignited only by the arrival of another signal. As long as the grid potential remains above the threshold value the tongue will chatter against the marking contact M, and by this means the signal can be made to actuate any recording device, such as a type-printing machine. It will be noticed that unlike other receivers the oscillatory valve relay embodies neither heterodyne nor separate detector. In the form in which it is shown here it is suitable for the reception of signals transmitted at speeds up to 40 or 50 words per minute. Inv. 1924-192.

description: This early high-frequency amplifier was designed for use with a gas triode of the type evolved by Mr. H. J. Round in 1915. As shown in the diagram, provision is made for negative grid bias from one or two cells controlled by a switch. and adjustable retroaction is included. Since the adjustments were critical, two separate valves were fitted, either of which could be selected for use. The input terminals of the amplifier are connected to the tuner in use. The retroaction coils are flat square spirals with hinged coupling.
interpretation: This early high-frequency amplifier was designed for use with a gas triode.

description: Lent by The War Office. First manufactured in April, 1917. This interesting amplifier represents one of the earliest attempts to make use of the triode in wireless telegraphy. It was designed for field use by the Signals Experimental Establishment during the War of 1914–18, and utilised two soft valves, a " White " valve and an " Audion " of the type evolved by L. de Forest from the Fleming two-electrode valve. (See Nos. 29 and 73.) A diagram of connections is shown, from which it will be seen that the amplifier is for high frequencies. The use of separate batteries for each valve and of a choke coil as the intervalve coupling should be noted. The first valve is arranged for retroaction and the whole amplifier is intended to be worked in conjunction with the standard pattern of tuner in use at the time. (See No. 50.) Inv. 1924-168, S.M. 2165.

description: This is an early three-valve low-frequency amplifier designed during the War (1914–18) for the magnification of audio-frequency signals. It consists of the orthodox connections for such an amplifier with the addition of one joining the H.T. positive terminal to a point on the primary winding of the first transformer. This connection was introduced to stabilise the instrument, which tended to self-oscillation. The primary winding of this winding has six tappings to enable the impedance of this winding to be adjusted to suit the impedance of the circuit to which it is connected. The telephone receivers are connected in the anode circuit of the last valve through the medium of a telephone transformer. The right-hand switch is for the simultaneous adjustment of the filament currents of the three valves.

description: This is a three-valve audio-frequency amplifier in which the first valve may alternatively be arranged as a detector. With the switch over to L.F. and the incoming leads connected to the terminals marked L.F., the circuit is that of an orthodox three-valve low-frequency amplifier. The primary of the first transformer is provided with tappings connected to a multiple contact switch, so that the ratio of transformation may be varied. The telephone receivers are connected to the plate circuit of the third valve through the medium of a telephone transformer. This set was designed for the magnification of:— (1) Earth current signals from power buzzers. (2) Signals of audible frequency from wireless sets. (3) L.F. signals from any other sources. With the switch over to H.F. and the incoming connections made at the H.F. terminals, the first transformer is cut out, the first valve being employed as a detector using anode current rectification by adjustment of the filament current. The second and third valves are independent of the filament rheostat, and perform L.F. amplification as before. The transformers in this amplifier were not designed for distortionless speech reproduction, but the apparatus is capable, nevertheless, of fairly efficient results when used for telephony reception.

description: In the type of resistance-capacity high-frequency amplifier shown at No. 141, the unavoidable capacity due to the triode and its connections between grid and anode may be of the order of 20 micro-microfarads or more. This capacity acts as a shunt condenser and seriously lowers the impedance of the resistance for high frequencies. For this reason amplifiers of that type are only suitable for comparatively long wave-lengths. By the use of special anti-capacity valves and by exercising care in the amplifier connections it is possible to make an amplifier capable of working fairly efficiently on wave-lengths as low as 200. Such an amplifier is here shown. It will be seen that the leading-in wires to the grid and anode of the valve are separated and brought in through separate seals. The practice is now common, but was first adopted by the French Military Service in this modification of their original general-purpose valve. A milliammeter is inserted in the anode circuit of the last triode, and serves to indicate the presence of oscillations when the reaction condenser is properly adjusted for this purpose.

description: This German amplifier was used during the War, 1914–18. The chief point of interest lies in the use of iron wire current limiters in series with the triode filaments. They consist of coils of iron wire enclosed in hydrogen in a glass tube, the resistance of iron increases with temperature, so that slight variations of filament current due to fluctuations in battery voltage are checked. The transformers have open iron cores and are shielded both magnetically and electrically by concentric cases of iron and brass. This can be seen in the example, which has been taken apart. The switch connects the receiver, which was made by the Telefunken Company, with the telephones, either directly or through the amplifier.

description: In this amplifier, designed by the French Military Service, there are five stages of high-frequency amplification, one of detection and two stages of low-frequency amplification. The first five stages are resistance-capacity coupled, and the last two have iron-cored transformers. For the purpose of obtaining high-frequency retroaction, as, for example, in the reception of continuous-wave signals, a special type of condenser, having one set of moving vanes and two sets of fixed vanes, is employed. By means of this condenser and a suitably connected switch, capacity can be introduced between any two of the electrodes in the high-frequency portion of the amplifier, and when these two electrodes are in antiphase reaction will occur. This type of amplifier was used during the War of 1914–18 with frame antennæ for the reception of long wave stations. As is well known, the use of resistance-capacity coupling for high-frequency amplification necessitates special precautions if the instrument is to be used with wave-lengths of the order of 600 metres. Such an amplifier is shown adjacently. (See No. 142.)

description:
This set was designed in 1918 for the comparison of the “C, Mark III” amplifiers (the connections of which are identical with those of the C, Mark IV when used for low-frequency amplification) against an accepted standard. The apparatus consists of three parts :—
(a) A generator giving an acoustic signal of definite pitch.
(b) A coupling unit, by means of which the signal note heard in the amplifiers can be compared with the unamplified signal.
(c) An artificial earth circuit. A diagram of the apparatus is shown. The set was also used for comparing the low-frequency magnification of the "R" valve in these amplifiers, to the shaft of a Wilson motor, to the shaft of which is fitted an aluminium disc with 24 iron teeth. These teeth pass in front of the magnet of a telephone receiver, and the combination forms a small power alternator. The shaft of the motor is fitted with a speed indicator, so that the alternator can be run to give a definite note. On the same board is an electric bell magnet, the hammer of which makes and breaks a contact which short-circuits the telephone magnet coil, and so interrupts the alternator current periodically, thus producing a current consisting of a succession of dots. Across the contacts of the electric bell magnet circuit is a 4 mfd. condenser, which prevents the noise due to the spark from passing to the amplifier. Piece B. The Coupling Board.—This consists of two large coils, one of which can slide along a graduated bar, so that the coupling between the two can be varied. The current from the alternator passes through the fixed coil; the movable coil being connected to the dummy earth (piece c) which is connected to the amplifier to be tested. The energy transferred to the amplifier can thus be varied by altering the coupling. To the fixed coil is coupled a small coil whose position cannot be varied. A change-over switch, which operates by pressing and releasing, enables one to connect the telephone to this fixed coil on pressing, and to the telephone terminals of the amplifier under test on releasing. The fixed coil yields a constant comparison signal. When the 'phones are connected to the amplifier they are shunted with a resistance of 70 ohms, which enables a louder signal to be amplified and so reduces the relative intensity of amplifier noises with the signal. Piece C. The Dummy Earth.—This consists of a choke (the primary of a transformer) and a series of resistances. The signal from the movable coil of piece “B” passes through the choke, and through a resistance of 14,000 ohms, with tappings at 50, 200, 800 and 14,000 ohms. The lines to the amplifier are tapped across these resistances by means of the 5-stud switch. The choke keeps a resistance permanently in the "earth” circuit, the respective resistances being selected to suit the earth-to-valve transformer of the C, Mark III amplifier. It will be seen that the apparatus enables the amplified signal derived from an amplifier to be compared with a signal of fixed intensity which is approximately that of an amplifier of satisfactory performance. Since the amplification from any actual instrument is not very constant, the method is more satisfactory than that of obtaining a direct comparison. Inv. 1924-178.

description: This is a transformer with primary tappings; used, in high-frequency amplification circuits, as a coupling device between successive amplifying valves. Since the strength of the rectified telephone signal varies as the square of the amplitude of the signal applied to the detector, it follows that an amplification of 10 times before rectification is equivalent in strength to one of 100 times after rectification. Against this must be set the relatively smaller amplification per stage which practical considerations have so far imposed on high-frequency versus low-frequency amplification, together with the difficulty which is generally experienced in suppressing undesired oscillatory currents caused by inter-electrode capacities in the valve. This transformer is designed for use on wave lengths of from 150 to 4,000 metres. No tuning condenser is employed, advantage being taken of the self capacity of the coil to obtain approximate tuning.

No tuning condenser is necessary with this coil, advantage being taken of the self capacity of the coil to obtain approximate tuning. It was designed for wave-lengths of 150 to 20,000 metres.

description: Made and lent by Igranic Electric Company. In the design of inter-valve transformers for low-frequency amplification it is important that the self capacity of the windings be kept as low as possible. The specimen here shown is interwoven with cotton yarn between successive turns and layers. The use of cotton as an interspacing medium is an advantage as it has a low specific inductive capacity, while the wire is bound tightly together and cushioned by soft non-resonating material. Such a structure prevents vibration of the wires in the coils. Five manufacturing stages are shown:— A. Paper tube to be covered with cotton. B. Completion of primary winding. C. Covering of cotton. D. Washers fitted and coil impregnated with insulating material. E. Section of finished coil. There are 3,000 primary and 15,000 secondary turns. Inv. 1923-25.

description: This is an example of the improved form of the standard transformer manufactured by this company for voltage amplification at audible frequencies. The coil bobbin is built up of special insulating material and the coils are each in six sections, this construction permitting a very low degree of self-capacity. The primary in this example consists of 3,000 turns of 42-gauge wire. The ratio of the primary and secondary coils is 4 to 1, the latter consisting of 12,000 turns of the same gauge wire. The primary and secondary inductances are respectively 10 and 150 henries; the self capacity being 18 m. mfd., and the amplification factor 31. The core is of stalloy iron, finely laminated with paper insulation. A curve showing the voltage amplification at frequencies between 200 and 4,000 p.p. sec., taken at the National Physical Laboratory, is shown adjacent.

description: This is a 24-volt accumulator battery of one ampere hour capacity for use in place of dry cells as a source of steady high-tension supply for small thermionic valves. The accumulator is of the lead acid type, the electrolyte being contained in glass tubes, of which there are twelve: a lead strip, bent to a U-shape, terminates as the positive of one cell, and at its other end as the negative of the adjacent cell. The cells are thus all connected in series, giving an approximately steady voltage during discharge of 24 volts. It is essential that the anode voltage of a valve should remain steady since the plate current varies as the 3/2nd power of this potential.

description: This was constructed by the late Mr. W. Duddell in 1900 for the generation of high-frequency currents, in connection with his experiments on the resistance of the electric arc; it was one of the first high-frequency alternators to be designed. An electric motor (not shown) was used to drive the two large metal disc pulleys, which turn a laminated soft iron inductor disc by means of a cotton belt. This disc had V-shaped notches cut on its periphery, and revolved between the two inwardly projecting poles of a laminated soft iron ring. The latter is wound with an exciting circuit, and also an armature circuit in which the high-frequency alternating current was generated. Frequencies up to nearly 120,000 cycles per second were obtained by driving one of the inductor discs (which had 204 teeth) at a speed of 35,000 r.p.m. The output of the machine was about 0·1 ampere at 2 volts, giving about 3·6 volts on open circuit.

description: The tikker consists of a small contact maker in which a couple of thin wires are brought together and separated by a vibrating electro-magnetic arrangement. The instrument was widely used for the reception of continuous-wave signals before the invention of the thermionic valve. If a continuous train of undamped waves is emitted from the transmitting antenna, for example in the case of a morse dash signal, the use of a simple rectifying detector at the receiving station merely gives rise to clicks in the telephone receivers corresponding to the beginning and end of the train. The principle employed in the “ Tikker ” is that of interrupting the flow of current to the telephones at an acoustic frequency by means of the vibrating contact described above. The received signals then assume an audible musical note of the same frequency. The apparatus was principally employed in conjunction with the Poulsen arc. Inv. 1923-398

description: The use of the arc to generate alternating currents was first investigated by W. Duddell in 1900, but it was not until 1903 that important modifications made by V. Poulsen led to the production of high-frequency oscillations of great power by this means. The modifications which he introduced were :— (1) The substitution of a water-cooled copper anode for the carbon anode previously used. (2) The use of a gas-tight arc chamber containing hydrogen. (3) The provision of a magnetic blast tending to drive the arc away from the electrodes. It was calculated that the aggregate power handled by arc transmitters in use throughout the world in 1923 was in the neighbourhood of 20,000 kw. The largest of these are capable of dealing with 1,000 kw. The arc here shown is an early example and would probably be rated at about 2 kw. The field winding is horizontal and is formed in two parts on either side of the arc chamber. The latter has been sectioned to show the interior.

description: This model is intended to show how a familiar phenomenon of general physics has been made use of in wireless telegraphy. When two musical sounds of slightly different pitch fall simultaneously on the ear, a regular throbbing is heard in the combined sound. These throbs are called “ beats,” and are utilised, for example, in the metropolitan police whistle. Similarly, two superposed oscillatory electromotive forces of supersonic frequency may be combined in one circuit to give a resultant current of differential frequency. If one of these electromotive forces is set up by a train of continuous frequency. waves of frequency N, and the other is due to a local source of frequency N', the resultant frequency will be (N–N'), and after rectification may be made audible in a telephone receiver. This “heterodyne” method of reception was invented by R. A. Fessenden in the United States in 1902, and is now almost universally employed in the reception of continuous waves. In the accompanying model, which may be operated with the controls provided, both frequencies have been brought within the audible range for demonstration purposes. description: This set is similar to the Marconi multiple tuner (see No. 48), and is interesting as having been designed to work with the early two-electrode valve of Prof. J. A. Fleming, F.R.S. With the switch in the “STD.BI” (stand-by) position, the antenna circuit includes a coil coupled to a closed circuit connected with the valve. description: First manufactured in 1917. The first continuous-wave sets for field use were made in 1916. description: This is a portable military set, designed for use in the forward area for ranges up to 4,000 yards, using a low single wire aerial, suspended at an average height of 3 ft. from the ground. The transmitting group consists of a transmitter Mark III*, a 30-watt high-tension unit and 10-volt, 16-amp. accumulator. The receiving group consists of a Receiver Mark III and selector. (a) *Transmitting Group.*—The transmitter consists essentially of a valve oscillator having tuned anode and grid circuits, and normally drawing its high-tension supply from a high tension unit, the action of which is controlled by the operating key. The folding operating key, aerial ammeter and tuning lamp are mounted on a metal panel and remain accessible when the cover is closed. High-tension current is supplied from a 30-watt induction coil, which takes 2.3 amps. at 10 volts from an accumulator and supplies 15-20 milliamperes at about 1,000 volts to the transmitting valves. The primary current for the H.T. unit and the heating current for the valve filaments are supplied by the same 10-volt accumulator, 6 volts being tapped off through a resistance for the latter purpose. On pressing the key this resistance is short-circuited, and the full 6 volts are applied to the filaments. A moment later the front stop of the key makes contact and closes the primary circuit of the H.T. unit, causing the latter to operate and supply high-tension current to the valves. The valve grid is connected with an aperiodic grid leak, consisting of a condenser of 0.001 mfd., shunted by a resistance of 6,000 ohms. The tuning of the aerial circuit is effected by means of an inductance tapped off to a 10-point switch, and fine tuning between the steps of the inductance is carried out by means of a spherical variometer coil. For longer wave-lengths, a fixed condenser is connected in parallel with the aerial tuning inductance, and this may be brought into circuit or cut out. The coupling between the aerial and anode circuits is varied by means of a reaction coil. A short and flexible lead named the "Anode Tap," the anodes can be connected with either the aerial end of the aerial-tuning inductance or some other point on this inductance. The change-over switch, which forms part of the transmitter, performs the following operations: in its "send" position it connects aerial and earth with the transmitting valve filament circuit, and disconnects the receiver from the low-tension battery; in its "off" position it connects the aerial, earth, and low-tension battery from the transmitter and receiver; in its "receive" position it connects aerial and earth with the receiver, closes the receiving valve filament circuit and opens the transmitting valve circuit.—In this instructional model the component parts of the continuous wave transmitter, Mark III, are mounted on a wooden baseboard. (c) The receiver is itself a valve oscillator and is so adjusted as to generate continuous oscillations of small amplitude, having a frequency slightly different to that of the incoming oscillations. As a result of this slight difference of frequency, "beats" of an audible frequency are produced. These pulses after being amplified by a second valve, arranged for low-frequency amplification, are applied to the head receivers and produce an audible signal. The 60-volt high-tension battery (not shown) fits within a cavity in the left-hand side of the case. The receiver may be used with or without a selector. If the selector is not in use, the aerial, earth and low-tension battery are connected with the receiver by means of the change-over switch. The current from the low-tension battery then flows through the two-valve filaments in parallel and is regulated by an adjustable series resistance. One end of the aerial and earth are connected with the aerial end of the inductance is connected through a fixed condenser, shunted by a resistance of 200,000 ohms, with the grid of the first valve, the other end being connected with the negative side of the high-tension battery is connected with the positive valve filaments, high-tension positive being connected through the reaction coil, with the outside winding of inter-valve transformer and the junction of a shunt condenser is connected between filament negative and the junction coil with the primary winding of the inter-valve transformer, in order to provide a path for oscillating currents. High-tension positive is also connected through the high-resistance winding of the telephone transformer with the plate of the second (amplifying) valve, the grid of this valve being connected to the secondary winding of the inter-valve transformer with filament negative. The telephone sockets are connected in parallel across the primary of the telephone transformer. (d) Heterodyne Wave-meter.—This wave-meter has a range of wave-lengths from 400 metres to 3,000 metres, and is itself a generator of continuous waves with an oscillating circuit consisting of a reaction coil, variable condenser, and a "French" type valve. The inductance and reaction coils are carried in coil boxes, one of which is used for wave lengths of 400 metres to 1,400 metres and the other for wave lengths of 1,200 metres to 3,000 metres. The variable condenser is calibrated with two scales to suit whichever coil is used. Tuning is carried out by means of a variometer. To tune the meter it is necessary to rotate the variable condenser until a silent point is reached, on either side of which "beats" at high frequency can be heard. The wave-meter may be used to tune the receiver or transmitter to a definite wave-length or to measure the wave-lengths of received or transmitted waves. (e) Selector and Rectifier.—The selector and rectifier units are optional attachments. They were used separately or in combination to obtain greater freedom from interference. The selector consists of a pair of coils with variable electro-magnetic rotary coupling between them. One of these can be connected across the primary of the inter-valve transformer, and the other has a variable condenser across it and forms part of the receiver circuit. The receiving portion of the set is thereby converted into a two-circuit instrument. The rectifier unit is for converting the alternating high-tension voltage obtained from the vibratory unit into approximately pure D.C. One or, alternatively, two triodes are used in parallel, their grids being connected together and to one terminal of the alternating high-tension supply. The heated filament is connected to one side of a reservoir condenser, the other side of which is connected to the other terminal of the high-tension supply. Half-wave rectification only is obtained by this means, so that the output is not a steady D.C., and contains an undulating component of the same frequency as the source of unrectified voltage, and a considerable lessening of interference was accordingly obtained by the use of this apparatus.

description: Designed during the War of 1914–18 to meet the demand for apparatus with low transmitting power to minimise jamming, and was first manufactured in 1919. This set was designed during the War of 1914–18 to meet the demand for apparatus with low transmitting power to minimise jamming, and was first manufactured in 1919. For this purpose a more sensitive receiver than usual was used, consisting of three stages of semi-tuned high-frequency amplification, a separate heterodyne, and a three-valve detector-amplifier. The set was troublesome to handle, chiefly owing to instability in the high-frequency stages, but ranges of ten miles with aerials 15 ft. high were obtained, and this at the time was satisfactory. With aerials 48 ft. high 100 miles was easily obtained. The set consists of a very simple transmitter of pure C.W., a highly selective tuner, and the amplifiers already described. The transmitter has an untuned grid circuit, and is fed either from a generator or from dry cells. Fine tuning between the studs of the A.T.I. switch is obtained by means of a variometer. The coils are wound with 9/40 stranded silk-covered wire. The tuner has two circuits with variable coupling between them. The coils all consist of three-layer step windings, and tuning is carried out by variable condensers connected across these windings. The tuner carries also a send receive switch. The high-frequency amplifier transformers are wound for 2,000 metres to 5,000 metres, primary and secondary windings, being interleaved in the grooves in the ebonite bobbin. Control of grid current is given by a potentiometer. The other amplifier is of the standard "Mark IV" pattern, described elsewhere in this collection. The heterodyne unit is also a standard instrument. (See "Heterodyne Wave-meter, No. 162 (d.).) Inv.
