description:
This interesting set was designed by the Army Signals Experimental Establishment in 1918 for continuous-wave transmission and reception in place of the light motor quenched gap spark set which preceded it. Rated at 120 watts input, the range of these sets was about 200 miles with a safety factor of 2.
Although not wholly satisfactory, either as regards efficiency or reliability, they represented a distinct advance on previous sets, much ingenuity being shown in the detailed design of the several units as well as in the general lay out.
Power for operating the set was drawn from non-spillable accumulators of 90 ampere-hours capacity. These, together with the set and the aerial equipment, consisting of two 48-ft. masts in sections and a twin aerial of length 300 ft. were carried in a light motor van which also served as office accommodation when the station was erected.
The transmitting apparatus on the left consists of a rotary converter fed from the accumulators and delivering alternating current at 40 volts, 900 cycles. This passes through an auto-transformer with tappings (seen in front of the transmitter) to control the power.
The voltage is now stepped up to 1,400, and is either fed direct to the two transmitting valves ("Tonic Train") or is first passed through the double-wave rectifier on the right of the transmitter, in which case approximately pure C.W. will be transmitted. The range of wave-lengths is from 600 metres to 2,500 metres.
The receiver (on the right) is of the two-circuit type, the secondary winding being provided with tappings which make it aperiodic when the switch is in the "stand by" position. Following the example of the Telefunken Company, this secondary coil is movable about two axes at right angles, so that a very loose coupling can be obtained.
A separate calibrated heterodyne circuit is incorporated in the receiver, and this can be used to tune both transmitter and receiver. For this purpose it is provided with a galvanometer and coupling coil to the transmitter so that resonance therewith may be indicated by the rise in grid current in the heterodyne circuit. A switch enables the operator to include in the grid circuit a condenser and leak resistance whose time period is of audible frequency, and when this is done the receiver can be tuned as from an ordinary buzzer wavemeter.
Detection and note magnification is carried out by means of a separate three-valve detector-amplifier.
A convenient switchboard enables the batteries to be rapidly tested, and the wiring is in all cases carried out by through lengths without joints, all connections or tappings being made at the instrument or switchboard terminals. The whole case is closed by drawing down a roller shutter for protection of the instruments. For transit this is further protected by a canvas-covered panel.

description: These two instruments together form a selective four-valve receiver, in which the first valve operates at radio frequency, the second valve acts as rectifier and the last two valves as audio frequency amplifiers. The switches are arranged to allow of the rectifying valve being used alone, or the radio frequency valve being added when required, and further, of either or both the audio frequency valves being added. The radio frequency valve is coupled to the rectifier by the reactance-capacity method; the reactance consists of a coil tapped at twelve points and controlled by a switch in order that the wave-lengths between approximately equal at all wave-lengths between 200 metres and 20,000 metres. The instrument is designed for hard valves of the original "French" type, and the grid of the radio frequency valve is maintained at a slightly positive potential to secure stability, variation of that potential being effected by moving the filament rheostat of the first valve. The audio frequency valves have their grids biased negative and are transformer-coupled. The tuner comprises an aerial or "stand-by" circuit with a switch and an adjustable reaction control. Fixed inductance coils of the plug-in type are used, controlled by a switch, and adjustable reaction control. The backs of the two panels have been removed and replaced by glass in order to display the wiring, and the method of winding the inductance coils may also be seen. Four aerial tuning coils, suitable for broadcast reception wave-lengths and nine coils suitable for general reception of longer wave-lengths are shown adjacent, one being sectioned to show the method of winding to secure reduced self capacity. description:
In the early days of radio-telephony, modulation was usually carried out by inserting a microphone directly in the antenna circuit. Since the microphones used in line telephony were only capable of handling a few watts without overheating, many attempts were made to provide others which could deal with heavy currents.
One such specially designed microphone is here exhibited, and was used by Capt. H. J. Round for radio-telephony experiments in 1910.
The problem of handling these large antenna currents was finally met, first by the magnetic amplifier of E. F. W. Alexanderson, and later by the introduction of thermionic methods of control, in which the microphone influences the antenna output through the medium of a chain of amplifying triodes.

description: This interesting set, which was intended for trench warfare use, but which was never issued in quantity, was designed by Capt. L. B. Turner for the unusually low wave-length of 50 metres. It consists of two units. One of these, the upper "unit," contains the transmitting and receiving triodes and their appropriate oscillatory circuits, and when in use is situated close to the antenna. The "lower unit" contains the necessary control apparatus and can be placed anywhere within reasonable distance of these, being connected to the upper unit by a multicore rubber cable. The high-tension current for transmission is derived from the hand generator or from a battery of dry cells. The transmitter, which is of the choke-control type, has a fixed tuned anode circuit with an aperiodic grid coil. Coupled to these circuits, which are used for reception as well as for transmission, is the antenna circuit which is tuned by means of a semi-adjustable condenser. On account of the low wave-length, and of certain peculiarly troublesome interaction effects which were encountered, the designer found it necessary to insert a coupling condenser of one micro-microfarad capacity between the antenna and closed circuits. The amplifier-detector comprises three stages of transformer-coupled high-frequency amplification, a detector triode utilising simple anode rectification, and two stages of low-frequency amplification. The anode potentials of all six triodes, and the grid potentials of the second and third stages, are finely adjust-able by means of potentiometers. The standard antenna equipment con-sisted of a single 40-ft. wire suspended between two 4-ft. masts, and following the usual practice, the “ earth ” connection was made to a 4-ft. mat of copper gauze laid on the ground. With such a low antenna and so short a wave-length, the screening effect of obstacles was naturally serious, but the range between a pair of these stations was seldom less than two miles, while in the open country six miles was by no means unusual.

description:
Made and lent by The Western Electric Company. This microphone is used for broadcasting, and in conjunction with special amplifiers and loud-speaking telephone apparatus to enable a speaker without raising his voice to address large public gatherings. By making use of trunk telephone lines, several such gatherings in different towns have been simul-taneously addressed by the same person.
In the case of the Public Address System developed by the Western Electric Company, the apparatus employed comprises a microphone—such as the one exhibited, to pick up the sound of the speaker's voice—a vacuum-tube amplifying arrangement, and one or more loud-speaking telephones to distribute the amplified speech-sounds. Each portion is designed so as to be as nearly distor-tionless as possible over the range of frequencies which constitute speech.
The microphone, is of a type known as the “ push-pull ” type, having two variable resistance elements, one on each side of the diaphragm. The latter is an air-damped steel disc, tensioned so as to have a natural frequency of about 8,000 periods per second. Owing to this high natural frequency and to the fact that it is damped, it responds uniformly to all the frequencies (200–4,000) which occur in normal speech. The two carbon buttons have each a resistance of 100 ohms and are connected in series, the electrical path being from the rear carbon electrode in each case through the carbon granules to a gold-plated area on the diaphragm itself. This double-button construction almost completely eliminates the distortion caused by the non-linear nature of the pressure-resistance characteristics of granular carbon. The microphone is suspended by springs to avoid vibration, and can pick up speech from a distance of five or six feet. On account of its special construction, however, its sensitivity is only about 1/1,000th that of the ordinary telephone transmitter, and this necessitates additional amplification. No horn is fitted to the microphone, as this would introduce resonance and consequent lack of uniformity of behaviour to all frequencies.
The complete system (of which the microphone is only a representative portion) has given remarkable results. On November 11th, 1921, speeches made at Arlington, Virginia, were heard by 100,000 persons there and simultaneously by 35,000 in New York and by 20,000 in San Francisco, telephone trunk lines being used in conjunction with the system.

object_name: Lent by The British Broadcasting Co. The distortion caused by the familiar “ multiple-contact ” microphone used in commercial telephone systems renders this microphone unsuitable, without serious modification, for the wireless transmission of music.
description:
In seeking to develop a type of microphone which should be as free from distortion as possible, the British Broadcasting Company took as their starting point the original form designed by Graham Bell in 1876. (See Telephony Section.)
In this instrument the vibrations of a circular diaphragm cause variations in the number of lines of force which thread a coil of wire wound over a magnet, so that alternating currents are set up in the coil, corresponding to the pitch, amplitude, and timbre of the sound.
Two examples of these experimental microphones are shown; they were used in the first London Broadcasting Studio in the early part of 1923, after the carbon microphone had been discarded.
Two or three of these Bell telephone microphones, having diaphragms of different thicknesses, and therefore different natural periods, were used in con-junction with one another in order to avoid distortion. It will also be noted that arrangements were provided for damping the diaphragms mechanically by means of adjustable rubber feet. The subsequent development of broadcasting microphones of this type is described adjacently. (See No. 175.)

description: This is the original Sykes microphone for broadcasting. From this instrument an improved form was developed by Capt. H. J. Round, of the Marconi Company, and was standardized for use in the London and other broadcasting stations in 1923. The Sykes microphone resembles the Bell form in that electro-magnetic reactions are utilised for the production of speech currents, but differs therefrom in the following particulars :— (a) An extremely heavy magnetic field is obtained by the use of a large electro-magnet. (b) An extremely light flat spiral coil is used as the moving element. This coil is suspended in the annular air gap of the electro-magnet, and alternating currents of acoustic frequency are set up in this coil by its own to-and-fro movement caused by acoustic vibration. The whole microphone is mounted in a rubber sling to insulate it from extraneous mechanical shock.

description: The oscillatory currents which are set up in a conductor by the passage of a group of electric waves are incapable of creating an audible sound in an ordinary telephone receiver on account of the frequency, which is too high. By means of a rectifying detector applied to a resonant circuit, however, the telephone receiver may be made responsive to any modulations which are taking place in the waves. These modulations may be introduced at the transmitting station for the purpose of conveying either telephonic or telegraphic signals, and the detector may take several forms. Only two, however, are now in common use, and of these the crystal detector is the simpler, though not the more sensitive. It has been used in various forms for over 16 years, and is very suitable for the reception of wireless telephony over a range of a few miles. The present receiver has been specially designed for this purpose. The receiver consists essentially of a variometer and condenser which can be connected either in series or in parallel by means of a switch ; when attached to an aerial and an earth connection it can be tuned to wave-lengths between 300 and 600 metres. Across this circuit are joined one of two alternative silicon detectors and a pair of telephone receivers. The latter are shunted by a small condenser in order to provide a path for the high-frequency component of the current. When a sensitive point has been found on one of the crystals and the circuit has been brought into resonance with the frequency of current set up by the arriving waves, an oscillating voltage is set up across the terminals of the detector, which owing to thermo-electric and other effects offers more resistance to currents in one direction than in the other. There then flows through the telephones a resultant current whose mean value is not zero and which causes them to give out a sound corresponding to any low-frequency modulations that have been introduced at the transmitter. A diagram of the connections is placed beside the instrument.

description: Made and lent by Messrs. C. F. Elwell. Inv. 1923-431.

This is an experimental radio-goniometer used by the inventor, M. Bellini, for directive wireless transmission. The British patent for this system, which has been very widely employed, was filed by Messrs Bellini & Tosi in 1907. In this system a pair of nearly closed triangular coils are fixed at right angles, and coils capable of being inserted in their lower portions, also at right angles. A third coil, which is missing from this original model, is placed close to, and within, the other two coils just mentioned, and forms part of the closed transmitting circuit. This third coil is capable of being rotated so as to be parallel with either of the fixed coils, or else occupy some intermediate position. It is found that the maximum intensity of radiation from the pair of antennæ is greatest in the direction of the plane of the primary inducing coil. The complementary apparatus for directional reception is identical with that described above, except that receiving and not transmitting apparatus is connected to the primary coil, which in this case is called the " search" coil. There are two other methods of radio-telegraphic direction finding which are widely employed at the present time; one of them is described under No. 181. Inv. 1924-498, S.M. 2177.

description: Made and lent by The National Physical Laboratory. 1916. This coil, which was designed in 1916, is believed to be the first direction finder to have been taken into the air. Experiments with it were successfully carried out on aircraft in 1917 and the method was immediately adopted by the Air Ministry. Similar experiments carried out on board ship proved equally successful and form the foundation of the development of the present day direction finder. The general principle of the method of determining the direction of an incoming wireless signal by means of a rotating closed coil may be briefly described as follows:— A flat rectangular coil is suspended with its plane vertical in such a manner that it is capable of rotating about a vertical axis. The coil is connected to a tuning condenser to form a closed oscillatory circuit, and leads from the condenser are taken to the usual form of detecting receiver. When the circuit is tuned to the frequency of the incoming electro-magnetic waves, an oscillatory current is induced of sufficient strength under favourable circumstances to give audible signals in the telephone receiver. The magnitude of this current is dependent upon the angle between the axis of the coil and the direction of the transmitting station. A simple consideration of the magnetic field associated with the incoming waves shows that when the axis of the coil points towards the transmitting station, the intensity of the received waves is a minimum. By rotating the coil, therefore, the minimum position, and hence the direction of the arriving waves can be determined. There is with the type of frame under consideration an ambiguity of 180°, since no indication is given as to whether the bearing of the transmitting station is (x) or (x + 180°), but this ambiguity is removed where direction-finding stations work in pairs on the ground. description: This alternating current rectifier operates by gaseous conduction in helium between cold electrodes. There is no filament, and the tube is capable of handling 100 m.A. at 1,000 volts, with a working life of 3,000 hours and upwards. The tube in the form here shown was developed by the American Radio & Research Corporation in the spring of 1923. The cathode, which consists of a hollow carbon cup, is held in position by means of a spring clip. The anode, formed of a small carbon button, is placed opposite a hole in the cathode. By means of shields all paths between anode and cathode, except that through the hole, are made shorter than the mean free path of ions at the gas pressure employed, so that conduction along these paths is not possible. Considering the behaviour of the tube when an alternating potential is applied, during the half cycles when the hollow electrode is negative the tube conducts, and the space between the electrodes becomes filled with a cloud of positive ions and electrons. Positive ions dropping from the cloud on to the inner surface of the hollow cathode liberate electrons. These proceed towards the anode and on their way ionize neutral gas molecules to form new positive ions, so that the discharge is maintained. The original electrons and those formed by ionization nearly all pass out sooner or later through the hole in the cathode, and thus reach the anode, which is solid. They do this rapidly and easily owing to their mobility, which allows them to speed up more quickly than the heavy positive ions, so conduction in this direction occurs with facility. For the reverse direction the solid electrode is the cathode, and positive ions under this condition will wander out from the hollow space through the holes and impinge on the solid electrode. Progress is slow, for they are large and heavy, and the gradient of the field up inside the cloud is weak, consequently conduction is very small in this reverse direction. Thus the tube acts as a rectifier.

The type here shown is still in common use, and is particularly suitable for cases where a compact condenser of large capacity is required for receiving purposes. description: During the War of 1914–18 it was found that the development of valve amplifiers made it possible to overhear telephone conversations or buzzer signals at distances of as much as two or three thousand yards from the line on which the signals were passing. This was effected by picking up the minute earth or induction currents, or both, on special circuits laid out in “no man’s land,” and then passing them through audio-frequency amplifiers. In order to prevent overhearing by the enemy, buzzer screening circuits of the type exhibited were laid out in an unbroken line along the front, their purpose being to set up vigorous audio-frequency currents in the earth which should create in enemy listening apparatus loud continuous or intermittent buzzing sounds through which the signals or conversations could not be read. The arrangement proved highly successful in practice, though the impossibility of obtaining definite information of its efficacy in any given case made it necessary to take other precautions as well. In this particular type of screening instrument a polarised buzzer of the pattern used in the "D III" telephone is made to give out two audio-frequency currents of different pitch. A separate interrupter armature plays between two contacts and sends these currents alternately to earth connections. Any stray signal currents picked up by hostile listening sets were then drowned by the bi-tonal accompaniment from the screening currents.

description: The elimination of atmospheric disturbances and of signals of undesired frequencies is a problem which has troubled wireless engineers at all times. Partial solutions have been offered by almost every inventor, but up to the present time the difficulty has not been surmounted. The instrument which is here shown is probably the earliest attempt at atmospheric and interference elimination. It proved remarkably successful in the circumstances in which it was employed. It was developed particularly for use at Babylon shore station, near New York, in 1904, where jamming from other stations was very severe, and its use was found to enable this station to transact messages with ship stations which had previously been impossible. The apparatus, which was used by Marconi in conjunction with his magnetic detector (see No. 33), consists essentially of three acceptor circuits arranged in series. (In this instance the circuits are arranged for tune "A" reception on 60 metres wave-length.) Earth connections are taken to each of the three inductances at tapping points which are nodes of potential at this wave-length; hence they do not take energy from the receiving circuit. When signals of the desired frequency are received they are able to actuate the detector in the ordinary way, but if disturbances of any other frequency arrive they do not go through the receiver circuit, but pass to earth at the nodal tapping points.

description: Four power buzzers of different makes are shown. One is of French design, one is a British instrument, and the remaining two are of German make. The object of all such instruments is to provide a means of signalling between two points without any intervening wire or conventional wireless link. (See "Buzzer-Amplifier Set," No. 194.) Apart from the interest arising from their development and use in the War of 1914–18, it is worthy of notice that many experimenters from 1846 onwards have taken advantage of the conductivity of the soil in order to transmit messages. It was natural that with the exalted sensitivity conferred on receivers by the invention of the thermionic valve the same measures should again be resorted to in time of war, in cases where aerials would be too conspicuous and cables destroyed by shell-fire. 1. The Parleur power buzzer was designed for the French Military Service. It is a spark induction coil of special design, taking primary current at a pressure of from 10 to 20 volts. The laminated armature nearly closes the V-shaped gap between the poles of the core, the air space being only about 0.25 mm. The armature is bolted to a stiff steel spring which carries one of the interrupter contacts on a thin projecting plate. The mechanical frequency of the interruptions is determined by the stiffness and inertia of the spring, and is arranged to be some 800 periods per second. The interrupter contacts are shunted by a 4-mfd. condenser. If the resistance of the earth connections is 200 ohms the secondary current is 0.2 amperes with 20 watts input. 2. The British design is similar to the foregoing. It was provided with three alternative armatures having frequencies of 640, 730 and 540 periods per second. 3. This German power buzzer has an oscillating armature arranged so that an alternating voltage is induced in the secondary winding and not a pulsating voltage as in the previous examples. A small incandescent lamp serves as a rough indication of the secondary earth current. 4. This is a more elaborate German instrument with two alternative buzzers, a safety fuse, and a switch to regulate the power.

description:
This set is designed for sending and receiving signals by means of vibrating currents sent through the earth. It is mainly intended as a subsidiary means of communication when aerials are inadmissible or have been destroyed by barrage, and has a range from 2,000 yards to 5,000 yards according to the nature of the earth connections and sub-soil.
The set includes a buzzer for transmission and a three-valve amplifier C, Mark III, for reception. Earth pins are placed at either end of a base about six yards length and these are connected with two spring clip terminals on a six-line commutator. Three different bases may be connected with the com- mutator and the desired base connected to either the buzzer or amplifier by means of a change-over switch. The buzzer consists essentially of an induction coil, the armature of which vibrates at a definite frequency. Current is supplied to the primary winding from a 10-volt battery, and when the transmitting key is pressed, the armature vibrates and a high-tension vibrating current is sent to earth via the change-over switch and commutator. Three interchangeable armatures having different periods of vibration are provided. A condenser is connected across the break to reduce sparking.
The three-valve amplifier is carried together with its high-tension battery (not shown) in the left-hand compartment of the case. The signals received pass through the commutator and change-over switch (set to “receive”) and enter the primary of the “earth to valve transformer.” The secondary of this trans- former connects the grid of the first valve to the negative limb of the valve filament through a dry cell, so that the grid is kept at a small negative potential with respect to the filament. This permits only a small current to pass in the grid filament circuit and the valves work under conditions such that the current between grid and filament is small and constant for small changes in grid volts.
The amplified signal from the first valve passes through the primary of an “inter- valve transformer,” whose secondary forms the grid and filament circuit of the second valve, through the dry cell. Similarly the amplified signal from the three-times amplified signal passes through a “valve to 'phone transformer” to the telephones.
The valves used are of the French R or A types.
interpretation: This set is designed for sending and receiving signals by means of vibrating currents sent through the earth. It is mainly intended as a subsidiary means of communication when aerials are inadmissible or have been destroyed by barrage.

description:
It is well known that in order to radiate powerfully electro-magnetic waves from an open antenna it must either be earthed or else connected with some form of metallic network possessing capacity to earth. In the construction of large permanent radio-telegraphic stations these earthing or balance capacity systems receive very careful attention, and months may be spent on their installation.
In the case of portable field stations, however, where the time taken in erecting the station may be limited to a few minutes only, it has been found that the best results are obtained by the use of mats made of woven copper wire. These are simply laid flat on the ground and exercise a dual function, since in dry weather they act chiefly as a counterpoise, while in wet weather they make a reasonably efficient earth connection.

description:
This instrument was invented by V. Poulsen. It consists of a long steel wire which, in process of recording, is wound off one drum on to another and passes under an electro-magnet. The current through this magnet is made to vary in sympathy with the sounds to be recorded.
In this manner the wire assumes a state of permanent magnetization, forming a magnetic record of the impressed sounds.
When it is desired to reproduce this record the wire is again run beneath the poles of the electro-magnet and a reproduction of the original sounds is heard in telephone receivers connected to the windings of the magnet.
The record remains stored in the form of magnetic flux for an indefinite time, but can be obliterated when desired by passing the wire through a strong mag- netic field.
The instrument has been used for recording wireless signals and it seems likely that the system may again come into favour for various purposes. The example shown is incomplete and in a damaged condition.
The visitor is referred to No. 29 (magnetic detector) for comparison, where telegraph signals are produced by magnetization and demagnetization of a soft iron wire which is being slowly carried through a magnetic cycle. Inv. 1924-188.

description: These sets were designed by Capt. H. P. T. Lefroy, R.E. The term "wired wireless" has been used to describe a system of multiplex electrical communication based on the use of one or more high-frequency carrier currents which are transmitted along wires or cables in the form of telegraph or telephone signals. Although some of the principles underlying such a system were already known it was not until 1910 that General G. O. Squier, of the United States Army, pointed out the practicable possibilities and described experiments made with high-frequency alternators. He also constructed portable buzzer-operated sets for field use, but, owing to the large attenuation constant inherent in the wave length used, 1,100 metres, the range of these sets was not great. Following on preliminary experiments in 1914, Capt. Lefroy, in 1915, designed for the British Army Signal Service a series of "wired wireless" sets working at four different frequencies which could be operated simultaneously on a normal telephone line, thus providing four extra channels of high-frequency communication. Two of these sets, which were used at the battle of Loos, are exhibited. They contain fundamental improvements, in that adjustments of the carrier frequency are effected independently of the line constants; while the frequencies are so chosen that a reduction in attenuation corresponding to a tenfold increase of range is obtained. A value of coupling was chosen to give the greatest strength of signals compatible with absence of interference from other sources. The later developments of carrier-current telegraphy and telephony for non-military use have been very rapid, chiefly owing to the use of triodes, and to progress in the design of filter circuits for separating the various high-frequency currents; thus, in April, 1923, there were in operation, between Pittsburgh and Chicago, 128 full duplex channels of communication, based on three carrier-current circuits. The four sets designed were given frequencies corresponding to wave lengths of 4,000, 8,000, 16,000 and 32,000 metres, and were known as A, B, C and D sets respectively, of which the B and C sets are shown. The range of the D set on a single open wire was 40 miles. From the diagram it will be seen that a closed oscillatory circuit, energised by a battery and vibrator, is inductively coupled to an acceptor circuit which is connected to the line and earth. This acceptor circuit is known as a "tuned link," and it is important to notice that in operation it is permanently tuned to the same frequency as the closed circuit, regardless of the line constants. The same oscillatory circuits are used, both for transmission and reception, the necessary connections being made by means of contacts on the signalling key. The buzzer-modulated high-frequency currents are transmitted along the line instead of being radiated as in normal wireless signalling, and a very small battery is used to afford a reserve of power. The received currents are rectified by a crystal in the usual manner. The design of the inductance coils should be noted; they are of the now familiar “basket” formation originated by Capt. Lefroy in 1914; they were the first low-capacity coils to be designed and possess a high ratio of inductance per unit of volume.

description: Non-inductive resistances of the order of a few megohms, of compact form and small current-carrying capacity, are frequently required in wireless telegraphy. description: These relays, which were patented in 1911 by Mr. S. G. Brown, are used to magnify receiver circuit currents so that messages may be printed on a tape machine or otherwise recorded, and very faint signals rendered audible. Two relays are shown fitted in a wooden case, together with transformers and a 6-volt battery. Both relays may be cut out of the telephone and receiver circuit, or one or both may be connected into it by means of a switch. Each relay consists of a permanent magnet with pole pieces on which two coils, connected into the receiver circuit, are wound. A steel reed vibrates in front of the poles of the magnet and is attached to one carbon electrode of a granular carbon microphone, the microphone chamber with the back electrode being held stationary. The microphone is joined in series with the local battery, the primary of the transformer, and an intensifying coil wound on the limbs of the magnet. The vibrations of the reed acting upon the carbon granules in the microphone cause telephonic changes of the current in the local circuit, which are intensified by the action of the intensifying coils and flow through the primary of the transformer. Currents are therefore induced in the secondary of the transformer, which act on the telephone receivers, or flow through the magnet coils of a second relay, according to the number of relays being used.

description: This telephone receiver, patented by S. G. Brown, is one of the most sensitive in use. Instead of the ordinary flat diaphragm there is a flexible steel reed to which is attached a thin conical diaphragm. The steel reed has one end fixed, while the other extends over the pole pieces of the magnet; it is cut away slightly at the sides, and can thus be adjusted to have a natural frequency of about 800 periods per second, which has been found the most satisfactory for wireless telegraphic purposes. A very light aluminium cone is attached to the reed by a small screw, and is supported at the top by a brass ring which rests on a light aluminium case, fitting over the magnet. Outside the back of the case is a thumb-screw, which enables the magnet to be adjusted, so varying the distance between it and the reed; the sensitive- ness of the receiver depends largely upon this distance, which can be set very accurately by the screw adjustment.

description: This is a portion of apparatus designed for the calibration of wavemeters for the three services, by means of a modification of Feddersen’s mirror. It was used for this purpose up to the end of 1915, but superior accuracy has since been obtained by the multi-vibrateur method. The complete instrument consists of two parts:— (A). A wavemeter (not shown). (B). Photographic apparatus for photographing spark trains, generated in the main oscillatory circuit by means of a gap and by help of a rotating mirror. (A) The wavemeter consisted of a variable condenser (from 100 to 900 m.mfd.) of special design, having a direct-reading scale, reading 1 in 1000 at the lower end, and 1 in 200 at the upper, carefully tested, and found by Maxwell's Commutator Method to be uniform. Three inductance coils were used, wound on ebonite formers, of stranded 7/36 wire, and having terminals removed 18.5 cm. from the centre of the coils to avoid interference from the condenser plates. A Duddell thermo-ammeter of 1.5 ohms resistance completed the coil-condenser circuit, and the point of maximum resonance was obtained by observing the point of maximum deflection. The wavemeter was very loosely coupled with the oscillatory circuit of the testing apparatus. (B). A small alternator of variable frequency (50 to 200 periods per sec.) was connected through a small high voltage transformer to a spark gap, having cadmium electrodes, shunted by a glass plate condenser, and a bare wire inductance in oil. A large variable air condenser could be put in parallel with the glass plate condenser, and by varying the capacity and inductance in circuit, oscillations of frequencies from 300,000 to 1,200,000 periods per sec. could be obtained. The special camera, which forms the exhibit, is mounted on a long slab of sandstone for rigidity. A rotating mirror was fixed on a vertical axis at one end, and driven by a small motor, the speed of which was kept constant by means of a commutator mounted on the axis. This was connected with a bridge battery and galvanometer for measuring capacity; by applying a light variable brake to the axis, the galvanometer light spot could be kept at zero, when the speed remained steady (usually about 60 r.p.m.). The other end of the camera has two branches which carry respectively the spark electrodes and means for allowing the plate carrier to be smoothly raised and lowered, whilst the rotating mirror throws the image of the spark trains as streaks upon the plate. By measurement the average distance from spark to spark was found, enabling the frequency to be calculated, taking into account the distance between the mirror and plate and the speed of rotation of the mirror. The mean of 5 to 10 spark train photographs showed an average variation giving an accuracy of 1/1000.

description: This is an early form of wavemeter designed by Prof. J. A. Fleming, F.R.S., and termed by him a cymometer. It consists of a variable condenser, constructed of a brass tube covered with ebonite, over which can slide a second close-fitting brass tube. The capacity of this condenser is variable in proportion to the displacement of the outer brass tube. Connected in parallel to form a closed oscillatory circuit is a variable inductance consisting of a wire wound helically round an ebonite tube, the turns being close together but not touching. Arranged to slide along this is an embracing clip, which is connected to the outer tube of the condenser, so that as the handle is moved the inductance is varied in proportion to the capacity of the condenser. The inner tube of the condenser is connected by means of a copper bar to one end of the helix. If electro-magnetic waves, from an outside oscillator, be allowed to fall on the copper bar, it is possible, by adjustment of the handle, to tune the cymometer to the wave-length of the oscillator, if this lies within the range of the instrument. The resonant condition is indicated by a neon tube connected to the terminals of the tubular condenser. Such a tube is remarkable for the brilliancy of the glow produced in it when placed in an alternating field, the position of maximum oscillation in the cymometer circuit being indicated by the maximum brilliancy of the tube. Since the capacity and inductance are varied proportionally, and the wave-length is proportional to the square root of the product of these two quantities, the scale of wave-length is evenly divided, the range on the particular instrument being from 100 to 1,000 metres. By the aid of this cymometer, measurements of small capacities, inductances and coefficients of coupling can also be made, but for all purposes it is now customary to use wavemeters of more compact form. description: This is a portable wavemeter consisting of a coil wound on a cardboard former, connected in parallel with a continuously variable air condenser, mounted on an ebonite panel. The arrangement can be tuned to wave-lengths ranging from 300 to 900 metres. If the switch is put to “λ 100–300,” some of the turns of the coil are short-circuited, thus decreasing the range of wave-lengths. The panel is provided with clips for holding a helium tube which glows when the meter is in resonance with as adjacent transmitter, a sharp indication being obtained if loose coupling is employed.

description: This is a wavemeter designed with three different arrangements of coils for wave-lengths ranging from 100 to 6,200 metres. With the two-way switch at “Summer” (Buzzer), the wavemeter can be used for transmission purposes, a small dry cell (not shown) being included in series with the buzzer. With the switch at “Zelle,” the detector cell is connected in series with the telephones in place of the battery and buzzer, and the receiver can then be tuned to the wave-length of the incoming signals by the adjustment of the condenser. The correct wave-length is read off from a chart supplied with the set.

description: This is a wavemeter made during the War of 1914–18 arranged in a small and portable form, so that it can be used for tuning and testing transmitters or receivers. It consists of a closed oscillatory circuit having a continuously variable air condenser and a fixed inductance coil. With the right-hand double-pole two-way switch at the “send” position, the buzzer with its battery is connected across the oscillatory circuit and energises it by a process of shock excitation. With the switch at “receive,” the battery and buzzer are replaced by a carborundum crystal detector and telephones so that the wavemeter acts as a receiver, and will respond to, and measure the wave length of, a transmitting circuit in its vicinity. The left-hand switch allows any one of three coils of varying inductances to be used, thus extending the range of the instrument.
